steps.title: Mix baking soda with water.
steps.content: Mix baking soda with water. Mix 3 tablespoons of baking soda and 1 teaspoon of water in a small cup. Stir the solution and continue to add water until a paste-like substance forms. It is important to combine the baking soda with water because baking soda alone is too harsh for your teeth and gums. [3] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Apply the mixture to your gums.
steps.content: Apply the mixture to your gums. Dip one finger into the mixture and place it on your gum line. Gently massage your gums with your fingers using small circular motions. You can also apply the mixture to your gums using a soft toothbrush. [4] X Research source Massage for 2 minutes. Apply the mixture 2-3 times a week. Stop using the paste if you notice that your gums are becoming more irritated.

steps.title: Alternatively, make an herbal paste.
steps.content: Alternatively, make an herbal paste. Mix one teaspoon of turmeric powder, half a teaspoon of salt, and half a teaspoon of mustard oil to make a paste. Use your fingers to massage the paste onto your gums twice a day. [5] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Leave the paste on your gums for a few minutes and then rinse your mouth. Alternatively, add 3 grams of chopped sage leaves into 150 millilitres (5.1 fl oz) of warm water. Boil it for 10 minutes, then strain the mixture to get a clear liquid. Use the liquid as a mouthwash. [6] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Both turmeric and sage have anti-inflammatory properties, and are often recommended for those dealing with gingivitis and periodontal infections. [7] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Purchase ozonated olive oil.
steps.content: Purchase ozonated olive oil. Ozonated olive oil is pure olive oil that has undergone ozonation, a process that turns it from a greenish-colored liquid to a white-colored gel. [8] X Trustworthy Source Science Direct Online archive of peer-reviewed research on scientific, technical and medical topics Go to source Studies show that ozonated olive oil has the ability to fight harmful bacteria and microorganisms in your mouth, as well as slow down the progression of aggressive periodontitis. [9] X Trustworthy Source Science Direct Online archive of peer-reviewed research on scientific, technical and medical topics Go to source You can purchase ozonated olive oil from an online retailer like Amazon. Ozonated olive oil has been shown to heal gum wounds after surgery. It may also improve the symptoms of oral diseases. [10] X Trustworthy Source Science Direct Online archive of peer-reviewed research on scientific, technical and medical topics Go to source Refrigerate your ozonated olive oil or keep it away from sunlight at room temperature. Many people have had good results with this treatment, but the only way to halt gum recession is to get medical attention from a professional. Ozone therapy is known to kill bacteria, fungi, and viruses, making it a common procedure to fight periodontitis. [11] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Brush and floss your teeth.
steps.content: Brush and floss your teeth. Brush your teeth with a soft toothbrush and non-fluoride toothpaste. After you are done brushing, floss each tooth to remove any plaque and debris. [12] X Expert Source Tu Anh Vu, DMD Board Certified Dentist Expert Interview. 10 April 2020. Be careful not to brush too hard before applying the oil.

steps.title: Apply the oil to your gums.
steps.content: Apply the oil to your gums. Apply 2 millilitres (0.41 tsp) of oil to your gums using your index finger, then massage your gum in circular motions for 10 minutes. [13] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Once you have applied the oil, do not eat, rinse, or drink anything for 30 minutes. [14] X Trustworthy Source Science Direct Online archive of peer-reviewed research on scientific, technical and medical topics Go to source You can also massage your gums with sesame or coconut oil. [15] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Do not use ozonated olive oil if you have had a recent heart attack, are pregnant, have hyperthyroidism, are intoxicated with alcohol, or have a hemorrhage in any of your organs. [16] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Put a tablespoon of oil in your mouth.
steps.content: Put a tablespoon of oil in your mouth. Oil pulling is used to remove impurities from your mouth. [17] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source You can use coconut oil, sunflower oil, or sesame oil. [18] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Coconut oil is the most popular, but it is solid below 77 °F (25 °C). [19] X Research source Since it’s hard to swish around a chunk of oil, blend it with sesame and sunflower oil so the mixture will not harden. [20] X Research source Children (5-12 years old) should only use 5 millilitres (1.0 tsp)-10 millilitres (2.0 tsp) of coconut oil. [21] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Sesame oil is the preferred oil of choice in Indian culture. Sesame oil is high in antioxidants, has antifungal properties, and has been found to reduce plaque-induced gingivitis. [22] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Swish the oil around.
steps.content: Swish the oil around. Swish 10 millilitres (0.68 US tbsp) of oil in your mouth for 10-15 minutes. [23] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source The oil will become thin and turn into a milky white color. The swishing motion activates salivary enzymes that absorb toxins and bacteria, so do not swallow the oil. [24] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source It is best to oil pull first thing in the morning on an empty stomach. [25] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source If you are unable to do 10-15 minutes a day, start with 5 minutes and work your way up.

steps.title: Brush your teeth.
steps.content: Brush your teeth. Once you spit out the oil, brush your teeth and rinse your mouth with water as you normally would. Oil pulling is not a substitute for regular tooth brushing and oral care, and it should be used as a supplement to what you usually do. [26] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Studies show that oil pulling may reduce plaque growth and build up, which are the main causes of gingivitis. [27] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source If you oil pull twice a day, you may see an improvement in plaque buildup in 14 days. [28] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Although the American Dental Association does not recommend oil pulling, it has been used for centuries to take care of teeth and gums. Even if you use this technique, see a medical professional to stop gum recession . [29] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Know the causes of receding gums.
steps.content: Know the causes of receding gums. There are many factors that can cause your gums to recede, and your dentist can help you identify any risk factors that you may have. [30] X Expert Source Tu Anh Vu, DMD Board Certified Dentist Expert Interview. 10 April 2020. Common causes of receding gums include: [31] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Trauma Periodontal disease Brushing too aggressively [32] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Abnormal tooth positioning Dental plaque or tartar buildup Being born with naturally thin or weak gums Smoking and using tobacco Having lip and tongue piercings

steps.title: Brush your teeth twice a day.
steps.content: Brush your teeth twice a day. Use a soft-bristled toothbrush to gently brush your teeth twice a day. Position the bristles at a 45-degree angle from your teeth so you can clean between your gums and teeth. [33] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source Brush gently in small, circular motions and short back-and-forth strokes, especially along your gum line. [34] X Research source Be sure to brush all the different surfaces of your teeth. [35] X Research source Brush your tongue when you are finished to keep your mouth clean. [36] X Research source Replace your toothbrush every 3-4 months or when the bristles become worn. [37] X Research source

steps.title: Floss daily.
steps.content: Floss daily. Flossing helps remove plaque that cannot be removed by brushing alone. [38] X Expert Source Tu Anh Vu, DMD Board Certified Dentist Expert Interview. 10 April 2020. Take about 12 inches of floss and wind it around your middle fingers. [39] X Research source Make a “C” shape when rubbing the floss between your teeth and gum line. Be gentle and never snap the floss into your gums. [40] X Research source You can use dental floss, a dental pick, or a pre-threaded flosser. Talk to your dentist about which tool is best for you. [41] X Research source

steps.title: Visit a dentist regularly.
steps.content: Visit a dentist regularly. The frequency of your dentist visits depends on the health of your teeth and gums. [42] X Expert Source Tu Anh Vu, DMD Board Certified Dentist Expert Interview. 10 April 2020. Most adults need to go once or twice a year. [43] X Trustworthy Source US Office on Women's Health U.S. government agency providing resources for women's health Go to source Your dentist will focus on preventive care and your overall oral health. [44] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source Board certified dentist Tu Anh Vu recommends going to the dentist “twice a year…every 6 months.” [45] X Expert Source Tu Anh Vu, DMD Board Certified Dentist Expert Interview. 10 April 2020.

steps.title: See a specialist.
steps.content: See a specialist. If your regular dentist feels that you need more intensive care, make an appointment to see a specialist. A periodontist can perform specialized treatments and surgical procedures to increase gum growth, such as scaling and root planing. [46] X Research source However, these treatments are typically expensive and invasive. Possible treatments to fix your gums include scaling and root planing, gingival flap surgery, or a gum graft, but your dentist will decide what is best for you. [47] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source
